FacilityName: Fort Lupton / Platte Valley / Lancaster Complex

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Western Midstream Fort Lupton Complex Executive Summary



This executive summary is a brief overview of the Risk Management Program and the associated policies at the Western Midstream Ft. Lupton/Platte Valley/Lancaster complex. The complex is subject to the OSHA PSM standard.



The Fort Lupton Complex is a natural gas processing facility made up of three separate processing facilities (Lancaster, Platte Valley and Fort Lupton) designed to process natural gas from wells within the DJ basin. The designed total capacity of this facility is 850 MMCFD. The main focus of these facilities is to process natural gas within acceptable pipeline specifications. Acceptable pipeline specifications mean the removal of water, CO2 and H2S. 



This facility takes raw and semi-treated natural gas into the facility from two different sources. Dehydrated high-pressure gas from field compressor stations delivered at approximately 1100 psig. The second source is from a low-pressure inlet that operates around 90 psig and is compressed up to approximately 1100 psig. The low-pressure gas is blended with the high-pressure gas for delivery to the Lancaster Plant. The Platte Valley and Fort Lupton plants use only the dehydrated high-pressure gas. The gas then goes through a process of cooling, using refrigeration, exchangers, and high-speed expanders to drop the temperature and pressure. This pressure and temperature drop help with the separation of the methane gas and natural gas liquids.



Reciprocating and centrifugal compressors are used to compress the methane gas up to approximately 900 psig and transported through pipelines to end users including the local utility companies. 



The second focus of the facility is to recover natural gas liquids from the raw natural gas. This liquid is then transported down pipeline as a "Y" grade product (all components combined) for further processing or fractionated on site into sellable by-products (ethane, propane, butane, and natural gasoline).

These fractionated products are then transported by truck to local market or pipelined for further processing. Third party raw natural gas liquids are also brought into the Fort Lupton Complex by trucks for fractionating. 



Prior to being fractionated the natural gas liquids must go through a sweetening process where excess corrosive gases (H2S and CO2) are stripped from the natural gas liquids. 



A sweetening process is also used to remove corrosive gases (H2S and CO2) prior to entry into the Lancaster plant. This process utilizes a solvent called Amine to remove excess H2S and CO2 from the gas stream. The amine is circulated through a contact tower where it comes into contact with the gas stream removing the excess H2S and CO2. This rich amine is regenerated to remove the corrosive gases. After the gases are removed the process starts over. The corrosive gases that are removed during the regeneration process flow through a reactor bed to remove the H2S then to a thermal oxidizer to incinerate any hydrocarbons remaining in the CO2 stream. 



A refrigeration system is used to add in the cooling of the processes. The refrigeration system uses propane as a refrigerant. The propane is vaporized during the chilling process, recompressed using reciprocating and screw compressors then condensed back down to liquid propane where it starts the process over. The refrigeration system is utilized in both the process plants and fractionators.



Hot oil is used to provide the needed heat to many processes within the facility. The hot oil systems are closed loop systems. The oil is heated as high as 425?F and circulated through various reboilers and exchangers in the processes as needed to keep products within the required specifications.   



The final process within the facilities is to stabilize the liquids brought in from the low pressure and high-pressure pipelines. Gas is separated from the liquids in inlet slug catchers with the gases being compressed for feed to t

he processing plants. The separated liquids are sent to stabilizers that heat the liquid to separate the ethane from the liquid. The ethane is recompressed and sent back to the facility inlet piping while the liquid is sent to storage tanks to be blended with the natural gas liquids for fractionation or sale to the pipelines.



A flare system provides a safe way of burning off excess gas from various processes within the plant (i.e., safety relief valves, pressure control valves, vessel/line blowdowns) during normal and emergency operations at the plant. The flare system can handle the full volume of the plant.



The total storage capacity between the three facilities exceeds the 10,000 lb threshold for these components and therefore the complex is subject to the requirements in the EPA Risk Management plan.



The facility has taken the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR Part 68. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the Release Prevention Program that are in place at the Fort Lupton Facility.



1.1. PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION



The Fort Lupton Facility maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to ensure safe operation of the processes. Process Safety Information includes information pertaining to hazards of the highly hazardous chemicals in the process, technology of the process, and equipment in the process. Examples of Process Safety Information include but are not limited to safety data sheets and process flow diagrams. Process Safety Information is updated using the Management of Change (MOC) process. This information informs employees of the hazards, safety precautions, and design related limits for the processes. 



1.2. PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS (PHA)



The Fort Lupton Facility uses one or more of the following PHA methods, as appropriate, to determine and evaluate the hazards of the process being analyzed:

-What if

-What If/Checklist

-Hazard and Operabil

ity study (HAZOP)

-Failure mode and effects analysis (FMEA)

-Fault tree analysis or

-An appropriate equivalent methodology.



The PHA is conducted by a team of people with expertise in engineering and process operations. The team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as prevention and mitigation measures currently in place and makes recommendations for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures as necessary to reduce risks to as low as reasonably practicable. Recommendations are reviewed by the Fort Lupton Management Team and after approval, corrective actions are assigned and distributed to impacted personnel for follow-up. 



Action items are tracked to closure as outlined in the Corrective Action and Preventive Action Procedure to ensure that all follow-up items are completed in a timely manner. Completed items are documented, and a copy of this document is placed in the PHA. PHAs are revalidated at least every five years. The revalidation includes a review of the changes and incidents that have taken place in the process since the last PHA and includes recommendations for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures. 



1.3. OPERATING PROCEDURES



Written operating procedures have been developed for each process area, which address initial start-up, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and start-up following a turnaround, or after an emergency shutdown. These operating procedures are stored electronically on an internal server for employee access and are periodically reviewed and revised. 



1.4. TRAINING



The Fort Lupton Facility's Training program includes formal on-boarding, job-specific training, compliance training, and safety training. Each employee involved in operating a process is trained in an overview of the process and in the operating procedures developed for that process. The Safety Manager or their designee is responsible for scheduling and coordina

ting the following training for PSM/RMP affected employees.



1.5. MECHANICAL INTEGRITY



Mechanical Integrity includes all activities required to ensure proper design, construction, and ongoing integrity and reliability of equipment in order to prevent or minimize incidents for the life of the equipment. The Fort Lupton Facility has several written programs in place that detail well-established practices and procedures for the inspection, testing, monitoring, and maintenance of process equipment. Mechanical Training is routinely conducted, and procedures are periodically reviewed and updated. 



1.6. MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE



The Management of Change (MOC) program is intended to cover changes to the process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures, and changes to stationary sources that affect a covered process. The Fort Lupton Facility reviews and approves a proposed modification at conception under the MOC/PSSR process prior to addressing the change. The MOC requests are tracked, and once all the required reviews are completed, the MOC is approved for change implementation. Training requirements for affected personnel will vary depending on the significance of the change. For changes requiring significant updates to procedures or equipment, special training sessions (meeting the training requirements of the company's RMP/PSM programs) may be necessary for operators, mechanics, and/or contractors. For less significant changes, simply communicating information about the change and its anticipated effects on operation/maintenance may substitute for training sessions.



1.7. PRE-STARTUP REVIEW



Pre-startup safety review (PSSR) must be conducted on new facilities and modified facilities when the modification is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information. The pre-startup safety process is used in conjunction with the Management of Change (MOC) process. If the change triggers a PSSR, then approval for startup also requires satis

fying the PSSR requirements. The PSSR process requires the appropriate personnel to field verify that the change was constructed and installed per the approved design and equipment specifications following the completion of the installation and prior to startup.



1.8. COMPLIANCE AUDITS



The Fort Lupton Facility RMP/PSM program is audited every three years and includes verification that the procedures and practices that have been developed to comply with the RMP Prevention Program and PSM regulations are adequate and being followed. Compliance audits are conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the process, and this person is impartial toward the facility or area being audited. The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to the Fort Lupton Facility Management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked to closure as outlined in the Corrective Action and Preventive Action Procedure. The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are kept on the internal server.



1.9. INCIDENT INVESTIGATION



An incident investigation must be conducted for every incident that resulted in or could reasonably have resulted of a regulated substance in a covered process. All incidents are reported and investigated according to the Incident Reporting and Investigation Procedure. Results of the investigation and lessons learned are then shared with appropriate personnel to prevent future recurrence. Any corrective actions resulting from the incident investigation are tracked to closure using the Corrective Action and Preventive Action Procedure. Incident Investigation reports are retained for at least five (5) years.



1.10. EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION



The Fort Lupton Facility encourages participation in Process Safety Management through training and the development of cross-functional teams to perform process hazards analyses, incident investigations and compliance audits. All

new and affected employees should be made aware of the RMP/PSM program as a part of the initial orientation process. All files associated with the RMP/PSM program are available as read-only to all Fort Lupton employees.



1.11. SAFE WORK PRACTICES



The Fort Lupton Facility has safe work practices in place to identify, assess and eliminate or mitigate risks associated with high risk work to ensure worker and process safety. Examples of these include but are not limited to: 

     Confined Space Entry 

     Energy Isolation 

     Line Opening/Breaks 

     Hot Work Permit 

     Entry Control 



The Fort Lupton Facility safe work practices along with training of personnel involved with these types of work form a system that aids in making sure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.



1.12. CONTRACTORS



The Fort Lupton Facility utilizes contract personnel to supplement maintenance work and also during planned shutdowns and construction activities. The Fort Lupton Facility goes through a selection process prior to allowing contractors to bid work in the facility. The facility obtains and evaluates information regarding the contractor's historical safety performance and current safety programs. After contractor selection, the Fort Lupton Facility informs the contractor of the potential fire and explosion hazards related to the facility operations, and routinely follow-ups with the contractor to evaluates the performance of the contractor work to ensure the contractor is meeting RMP/PSM and other safety obligations.



1.13. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



During the last five years, there have been no accidents that meet the criterion for inclusion in this submittal.



1.14. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN



The Fort Lupton Facility is a non-responding facility and had not had a recent significant release of hazardous substance defined by the RMP Rule for the covered processes. The Fort Lupton Facility has a written emergency response program (ERP) which has

been developed in accordance with OSHA PSM Requirements. The plan identifies steps to be taken in case of an accidental release, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plan and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies if a release occurs and post incident cleanup.



1.15. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

 

The Fort Lupton Facility constantly reviews our safety program and institute revisions as appropriate to enhance safety and promote continuous improvement of our operations.
